report_title: Printing, Paper, Food, Textile & Other Machinery Manufacturing Industry Report
executive_summary: Printing, paper, food, textile and other machinery manufacturing is a collection of several subsegments that produce industrial machinery for their downstream manufacturing industries. Demand hinges on activity in discrete downstream markets, as downstream producers purchase machinery in response to domestic and international demand for manufactured goods. Due to this, the industry is influenced by the overall level of industrial production and the amount of private investment in industrial equipment across the economy.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC BROUGHT ON EXTREME VOLATILITY IN THE MACROECONOMIC ENVIRONMENT
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Downstream apparel manufacturers have largely offshored operations, taking entire supply chains with them and limiting domestic demand for related machinery, such as sewing and embroidery machines. Supply chain efficiencies, lower wage costs and fewer regulations have enabled manufacturers in foreign countries to produce machinery at lower prices than their US counterparts. In turn, these savings are passed on to the consumer in the form of lower prices, siphoning revenue away from domestic manufacturers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Low-Cost Imports Siphon Revenue Away From Domestic Manufacturers, While Input Price Volatility Hinders Profit

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: IMPROVED ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND A DEPRECIATING DOLLAR WILL PROPEL DEMAND
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Demand for the food-processing machinery segment will be driven by increasing demand for processed foods and greater automation of food production, particularly in emerging economies. New technology and food safety concerns will continue to benefit the food-processing segment. In particular, demand for easy-to-clean equipment will rise in light of greater public and government scrutiny surrounding food safety and hygiene.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Push for Higher Safety and Hygiene Will Increase Food-Processing Machinery Production

industry_definition: Operators in this industry manufacture diverse industrial machinery, including machinery for food processing (e.g. ovens), sawmills and paper industries (e.g. log splitters), printing industries (e.g. printers) and other industries (e.g. knitting machinery and kilns). This industry does not contain information on semiconductor machinery manufacturing in the United States (see IBISWorld report 33329a).

opportunities: High Performance Drivers: Industrial production index
threats: Low Outlier Growth: Private investment in industrial equipment and machinery

key_trends: Competitive pricing is key to attracting downstream customers in a relatively low-margin industry. Printing, paper, food, textile and other machinery manufacturers must also be able to deliver a range of high-quality products.
A diverse product line at various price points and quick turnaround is important. Due to the constant threat of low-cost imports, domestic

market_segmentation.segment_description: Food manufacturers use industry-relevant machinery to transform raw agricultural and dairy ingredients into intermediate and final consumer goods.

Printing industries produce books, magazines, newspapers and other paper-based media on a mass scale. The printing industry's share of revenue has fallen over the past five years and will continue to decline, largely due to digital substitutes replacing paper-based media.

Machines demanded by this market are diverse and various factors influence their demand, some of which offset each other. For example, chemical manufacturers represent a large part of this market because of the value-adding processes performed by these machines. In contrast, revenue from textile industries has declined as US investments in relevant machinery have weakened as textile production has shifted overseas.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment traditionally accounts for a large proportion of industry revenue, reflecting the diversity of manufacturing equipment this industry produces. It includes numerous products for equally disparate downstream industries, including machinery for electronic components, industrial process equipment (e.g., kilns and gas liquefiers), materials machinery (e.g., tile making, glass making and stone working) and still other machinery (e.g., cigarette rollers and tobacco processors).

This segment includes industrial equipment used to handle and process specific food products, such as baked goods, dairy, meat, poultry, snacks, fruits and juices. It also includes generic food-processing equipment, including slicers, sorters, grinders, roasters, mixers, choppers and presses.
Printing machinery includes prepress equipment, binding machinery and printing presses.

Machinery for the paper and paperboard industries includes pulp digesters, makers and molders, papermaking machines (e.g., coaters, finishers, corrugators, cutters and folders) and sandpaper machinery.

This segment includes machinery for making bobbins, cordage and rope, lace, nets, silk screens, threads, wool and yarn, among others. Specific machinery includes beamers, bleachers, braiders, combers, carders, extruders, embroiderers, looms, finishers, printers, winders and texturizers.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The composite nature of this industry makes it difficult to isolate any specific factor that affects demand for printing, paper, food, textile and other machinery. The industrial production index serves as a macro-level indicator of manufacturing in the United States. As the volume of industrial production contracts increases, demand for manufacturing products also does.

international_trade_points.trade_title: The industry contends with a trade deficit
international_trade_points.trade_description: The industry imports more than it exports due to cheaper labor costs and looser regulations overseas. This trade deficit has widened due in part to an appreciating US dollar.

Before the period, the United States imposed tariffs on various Chinese import items, including steel products. The tariffs were implemented as a retaliatory measure against China's US technology and intellectual property exploitation. Still, China remains one of the largest importers of printing, paper, food, textiles and other machinery. This trend is expected to continue over the outlook period.

international_trade_points.trade_title: The Largest Destination for Industry Exports is Canada, Followed by Mexico
international_trade_points.trade_description: Industry trade with Canada and Mexico benefits from advantageous trade conditions with the United States through the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA). This agreement, which replaced NAFTA, dramatically reduced tariffs on goods flowing among these neighboring countries and boosted total trade activity.

international_trade_points.trade_title: A Depreciating Dollar Will Boost Export Volumes Over the Next Five Years
international_trade_points.trade_description: A decreasing trade-weighted index (TW), which measures the strength of the US dollar relative to the currencies of its major trading partners, will benefit industry exports as domestically produced goods become comparatively less expensive for foreign customers.

business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region has historically been a center for paper product manufacturing, with access to raw materials and proximity to large markets in the eastern United States and Canada.

Within the Southeast region, concentration of establishments is in the Carolinas and Georgia. The main reason for the heavy concentration of fiber, yarn and textile mills in the Southeast region is due to the presence of cotton farms and the establishment of textile, fabric and carpet mills in the early 1900s.

The West's coastal location and high population density are highly beneficial. California ranks first among the top five states across all machinery segments except paper mill-related machinery. The state's dominance benefits from widespread access to ports and high population densities along its large coast.
The Mid-Atlantic region is known for its traditional manufacturing sectors and proximity to major markets.
The Plains region supports various industries including agriculture and manufacturing due to its central location.
The Southwest region has been developing its manufacturing base, especially in machinery.
New England has a historical influence on manufacturing and technology with its proximity to major educational institutions.
The Rocky Mountains region possesses natural resources and a growing market for manufacturing.

regulations_points.regulation_title: PRODUCT STANDARDS MUST BE ADHERED TO
regulations_points.regulation_description: Product standards fall into three categories: communication standards define the basic terms and symbols for safety decals and warnings; design standards establish dimensions, tolerances or other physical product characteristics; and performance standards provide a voluntary method of rating products.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Clean Water Act (CWA), The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) and The Clean Air Act (CAA)
regulations_points.regulation_description: Under the CWA and RCRA, manufacturers are responsible for following appropriate water and solid waste discharge procedures. They are also subject to specific provisions relating to airborne pollution emissions.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Cluster Rule and Noise Control
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Cluster Rule protects human health and the environment by reducing toxic releases to the air and water. The rule applies to most manufacturers in the United States and is enforced by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).

In response to Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidance, various levels of regulation have been implemented in the United States and overseas to discourage public gatherings, large events or crowded, unsafe work environments.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is in a mature life cycle stage.
The capital intensity level for the industry is low.
The industry assistance level is high and steady.
The concentration level in the industry is low.
Manufacturers are required to comply with environmental laws, including noise pollution, solid waste emissions and treatment.
To effectively compete and gain a sizable market share, manufacturers have high start-up costs for machinery, materials and employees.
Manufacturers maintain their competitive position through substantial capital investment in research.
Manufacturing is highly labor-intensive, requiring skilled workers to operate machinery.

basis_points.basis_title: Competitive pricing key to attracting customers
basis_points.basis_description: Competitive pricing is key to attracting downstream customers in a relatively low-margin industry.
Printing, paper, food, textile and other machinery manufacturers must also deliver a range of high-quality products.

basis_points.basis_title: Diverse product line and quick turnaround important
basis_points.basis_description: A diverse product line at various price points and quick turnaround is important.

basis_points.basis_title: Tight profit margins due to low-cost imports
basis_points.basis_description: Due to the threat of low-cost imports, domestic manufacturers tend to have tight profit margins.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Competition varies by geography and product line
concentration_points.concentration_description: The diversity of products and markets included in the industry limits potential for any single business to secure significant market share.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Companies try to specialize within segments
concentration_points.concentration_description: Manufacturers often specialize within a segment to retain competitive advantage.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Large manufacturers better withstand volatile input prices
concentration_points.concentration_description: Major companies are better equipped to absorb fluctuations in steel and aluminum prices.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Large manufacturers less impacted by economic slowdowns
concentration_points.concentration_description: Revenue for large manufacturers has fluctuated less than that of smaller manufacturers during economic downturns.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases as a share of revenue have increased over the past five years, primarily because of sharply rising steel prices.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Skilled Labor is Highly Important, Resulting in High Wage Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages as a share of revenue have increased over the past five years.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Increasing Wage and Purchase Costs Hampers Profit
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit as a share of revenue has decreased, with labor costs outpacing revenue growth.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Manufacturing is highly labor-intensive, requiring skilled workers.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Revenue is Highly Influenced by Macroeconomic Activity and Downstream Manufacturing
volatility_points.volatility_description: The severe economic disruption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic has contributed to moderate volatility.

volatility_points.volatility_title: THE HIGHLY VOLATILE PRICE OF STEEL CAN SHIFT DEMAND PROSPECTS
volatility_points.volatility_description: Industry selling prices depend on the price of steel and other manufacturing inputs.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: MACHINERY AFFORDABILITY IS PRIMARY AREA OF IMPROVEMENT
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Manufacturers aim to supply advanced equipment but face affordability challenges.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Technological Innovations are Streamlining the Manufacturing Process
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Investments in technology help maintain cost structure competitiveness.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by imports?
FAQs.answer: Imports compete with products on a cost basis due to their low-wage costs.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche or do you produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Some manufacturers are able to specialize in a niche.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Input prices for metals such as steel have fluctuated.

FAQs.question: Have you looked into setting up manufacturing facilities in lower-wage regions of the country?
FAQs.answer: Outsourcing manufacturing to low-cost regions helps reduce wage costs.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology?
FAQs.answer: Automation enhances manufacturing capacity and standardization.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations?
FAQs.answer: Participation in industry assistance groups keeps some manufacturers informed of industry news.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Implementation of standard operating procedures is essential.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected profit margins over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: Volatile input prices can affect industry profit margins.
